2009/7/28 Jeff Clune <jclune@...>:
>
>> It's trivially simple to add a genome size punishment factor into the
>> fitness function, just use something like:
>>
>> fitness = fitness / (connectionCount + C)
>>
>> and maybe scale the fitness back up with some fixed multiple, so:
>>
>> fitness = (fitness * A) / (connectionCount + C)
[...]
>> I've also used this approach to limit overfitting of target data, put
>> simply, smaller ANNs are less likely to specialize and overfit than
>> larger ones. I guess you could say it's a form of regularization.
>
> That sounds like a good idea. Did you find that it worked?

Let's just say that I believe there are a class of problems where you
want to bias the search towards a more thorough search of the simpler
topologies before moving on to more complex ones. Where overfitting is
a concern you want that bias to be large and you can probably put a
finger in the air and come up with a maximum complexity beyond which
you can be sure the ANNs have overfit the data and are therefore
useless.

Colin
